text: We are looking at the backs of two people in the front se a man, driving, and a woman next to him. Their conversation will be punctuated by the occasional g of oncoming headlights and the roar of the car rushing by The windshield wipers wave a soporific beat. The conversa is halting, awkward.
...He gave me a little pearl-handled  .38 for out first anniversary.
Uh-huh.
...Figured I'd better leave before I  used it on him. I don't know how you  can stand him.
Well, I'm only an employee, I ain't  married to him.
Yeah...
Pause, as an oncoming car passes. Finally:
...I don't know. Sometimes I think  there's something wrong with him.  Like maybe he's sick? Mentally?...  Or is it maybe me, do you think?
Listen, I ain't a marriage counselor.  I don't know what goes on, I don't  wanna know... But I like you. I always  liked you...
Another car passes.
...What're you gonna do in Houston?
I'll figure something out... How  come you offered to drive me in this  mess?
I told you. I like you.
See, I never knew that.
Well now you do.
...Hell.
Another pause. Another car. Suddenly:
Stop the car, Ray!
Stamped on.
Low three-quarters on the car as it squeals to a halt. A car that has been following screeches to a halt just be it. Both cars sit. Rain patters.
Close on the man, from behind. He looks at the woman.
...Abby?
She doesn't answer. He turns to look back and we see his  face, for the first time, in the headlights of the car be

The car behind them waiting, patiently. Rain drifts down  past its headlights. Finally it pulls out and passes them slowly, their headli showing it to be a battered green Volkswagon. First the c itself, then its red taillights, disappear into the rain.
Cutting between him and the woman, each from behind.
...You know that car?
No.
What's the matter?
I don't know... I just think maybe  I'm making a mistake...
She looks at the man.
...What was that back there?
Back where?
Sign.
I don't know. Motel... Abby--
Ray. Did you mean that, what you  said before, or were you just being  a gentleman?
Abby, I like you, but it's no point  starting anything now.
Yeah.
I mean, I ain't a marriage counselor--
Yeah.
The man is uncomfortable.
...What do you want to do?
The woman is uncomfortable. After a long pause:
...What do you want to do?

Pulling back from RAY and ABBY in bed, making love. The only light is from cars passing along the highway out Each sweeping light-by ends in black. The pullback ends in a wide shot of the motel room. The b following the last car lingers. A telephone rings.
Ray and Abby are asleep. On a nightstand next to the bed, the telephone is ringing. Ray stirs, reaches for the phone.
...Hello.
Having a good time?
...What? Who is this?
I don't know, who's this?
A silence at both ends.
...You still there?
Yeah, I'm still here.
Ray listens to another silence. It ends with a disconnect Abby is stirring as Ray gets out of bed.
...Ray?
Yeah.
What was that?
Your husband.

We are tracking past a man seated behind a wooden desk,  towards an 8 x 10 black-and-white photograph that has jus been slapped down on the desktop. The picture is of Abby and Ray in bed together in the mot room.
I know a place you can get that  framed.

The voice is familiar as that of the narrator whose musin on life in Texas and the Soviet Union opened the movie. We cut to him. He is settling himself into a chair facing the desk. He i LOREN VISSER, a large unshaven man in a misshapen yellow  leisure suit. He smiles at the man behind the desk.
Sits staring down at the photograph. Behind him a window  opens on the bar proper. Country-western music filters in from the bar. Marty is not pleased.
What did you take these for?
What do you mean...
He removes a pouch of tobacco from his breast pocket and  nonchalantly starts rolling a cigarette.
...Just doin' my job.
You called me, I knew they were there,  so what do I need these for?
Well, I don't know... Call it a fringe  benefit.
How long did you watch her?
Most of the night...

He lights his cigarette, then slaps his lighter onto the  desktop. It is silver, engraved on the top with a lariat spelling "Loren" in script, and on the side with a declaration tha he is "Elks Man of the Year."
...They'd just rest a few minutes  and then get started again. Quite  something.
Marty stares down at the photograph.
You know in Greece they cut off the  head of the messenger who brought  bad news.
A smoke ring floats into frame from offscreen.
Now that don't make much sense.
No. It just made them feel better.
Marty rises and goes to a safe behind his desk. Visser laughs as he watches Marty.
Well first off, Julian, I don't know  what the story is in Greece but in  this state we got very definite laws  about that...
Marty, hunched over the standing safe behind his desk, to in the photograph and takes out a pay envelope.

...Second place I ain't a messenger,  I'm a private investigator. And third  place--and most important--it ain't  such bad news. I mean you thought he  was a colored. (he laughs) ...You're always assumin' the worst...
Visser blows another smoke ring, pushes a fat finger thro the middle of it, and beams at Marty.
...Anything else?
Yeah, don't come by here any more.  If I need you again I know which  rock to turn over.
Marty scales the pay envelope across the desk. It hits Vi in the chest and bounces to the floor. Visser looks stonily down at the envelope; no expression a beat. Then he roars with laughter.
That's good... "which rock to turn  over"... that's very good...
Sighing, he leans forward to pick up the envelope. He ris straightens his cowboy hat, and walks over to a screen do letting out on the bar's back parking lot.
Well, gimme a call whenever you wanna  cut off my head...
He pauses at the door, cocks his head, then turns back to the desk and picks up his cigarette lighter. Returning to the door:
...I can crawl around without it.

The door slams shut behind him. Marty scowls at the back door. After a moment he rises an crosses the office to the window looking out on the bar. Over Marty's shoulder we see the long bar leading up to t window in perpendicular. The camera is tracking forward,  past Marty, to frame on the window. A black man is just now vaulting the near end of the bar, over onto the customer side.

Tracking back with him as he lands on the customer side a heads across the bar. This shot, from the other side of t back-office window, reveals the window to be one-way glas mirrored on this side MEURICE, the black bartender, is muscular, about 200 poun dressed in white pants and a sleeveless T-shirt. He is ma his way through the crowd towards the jukebox. Another man stands in front of it examining the selection He deposits a quarter.
Hold it, hold it. What's tonight?
What?
What night is it?
(studying Meurice) ...Friday?
Right. Friday night is Yankee night.  Where're you from?
Lubbock?
Meurice shakes his head and punches the selector buttons the jukebox.
Right. I'm from Detroit (turning to leave) It's a big city up north with tall  buildings.

A Motown song drops. We track behind Meurice as he makes way back toward the bar. When he reaches it, he claps a c of people on the shoulder, who make way for him. He vault back over the top, walks down the bar, and stops in from an attractive white woman sitting on a bar stool and sipp a brandy.
Where was I?
You we telling me about the Ring of  Fire.

Yeah, well, I may be getting in over  my head here, I mean you're the  geologist, but my theory for what  it's worth, you got all these  volcanoes and each time one pops  it's the equivalent of what, twenty,  thirty megatons of TNT?  Enough to  light Las Vegas for how long?  How  many years? Course, I'm no  mathematician but--
Meurice.
Marty is approaching from the direction of the office.
Yeah, I know. Pour 'em short.
Has Ray come in yet?
No, he's off tonight. Where was he  last night?
(glaring) How would I know?
I don't know, didn't he call?
Marty loses his glare and his gaze drifts over to the wom After an awkward pause, Meurice clears his throat.
...Marty, I'd like you to meet an  old friend of mine, Debra. Debra,  this is Julian Marty, the dude I'm  always talking about.
She is unselfconsciously returning Marty's stare.
If he does come in I'm not here...  What were you drinking, Debra?
Remy.
You've got a very sophisticated  palate.
Thanks.
Give Debra here another drink, and  give me the usual.
Meurice walks down the bar.
...What's a palate?
Marty studies her for a beat, she studies him, he smiles.
Listen, I got tickets for the Oilers  and the Rams next week in the  Astrodome. Ever sat on the fifty  yard line?
I don't follow baseball.
Marty laughs.
You won't have to. I'll explain what  a palate is.
You won't have to. I just wanted to  see if you knew.
Marty smiles bleakly. Debra drains her glass as Meurice  returns. He sets another Cognac in front of Debra, and a  glass of milk in front of Marty.
What's this?
You said the usual--
Red Label.
(picking up the milk) Right. Sorry.
Pour that back.
What.
Don't throw that out.
Right.
He wanders on down the bar; Marty's attention returns to woman.
So how long have you know Meurice?
About ten years.
Marty's attention is caught by something down the bar. He half-rises from his stool.
What--Waitaminute--What...
Meurice is pouring the milk down the sink. He looks innoc up.
What.
Angry but not knowing what to say. He glances around the  bar, sinks slowly back onto his stool.
Deuce in the corner needs help.
Right.
Marty sits staring across the bar for a moment, nods a co of times at nothing in particular, then looks back at the woman.
...So what're you doing tonight?
Going out with Meurice.
Marty tosses a beer nut into his mouth.
Tell him you have a headache.
Debra gives him a level stare.
It'll pass.
We don't seem to be communicating--
You want to hustle me. I don't want  to be hustled. It's as simple as  that. Now that I've communicated,  why don't you leave?
I own the place.
Christ, I'm getting bored.
I'm not surprised, the company you've  been keeping the last ten years.
They both fall silent as Meurice enters frame. He takes a bottle from the bar and pours himself a drink.
What's this?
What.
(pointing at Meurice's  drink) This.
Jack Daniels. Don't worry, I'm paying  for it.
That's not the point.
What's the point?
The point is we don't serve niggers  here.
Where? (he looks over his  shoulder; up and  down the bar) ...I'm very careful about that.
Marty tosses back Meurice's drink, then turns to Debra,  smiling.
He thinks I'm kidding. Everybody  thinks I'm kidding; (as he turns to leave) if Ray comes in I'm not home.
Debra watches him go, then turns back to Meurice.
Nice guy.
Not really. What'd you say your last  name was?

We are following a large German shepherd as it pads down hall toward a warmly lit room at its end. We hear only th sound of the dog's paws on the hardwood floor, and the fa clicking of billiard balls.

It is a paneled, carpeted room with black leather furnitu and a nine-foot billiard table. Various stuffed animal  trophies are scattered around the room, including a moose head mounted on one wall. Ray stands alone in the foregro shooting pool, an unlit cigarette in his mouth. The room very quiet. In the background the German shepherd enters from the hal sits down in a corner, and benignly watches Ray.

It is expensively appointed; a brightly lit woman's bedro Abby is opening a hinged drawer in a white antique bureau She pulls out a leather handbag, gropes nervously through its contents, then puts it aside. She crosses the room to a vanity table, takes a purse fro underneath, and spills its contents out on top of the tab
Ray pockets a couple of balls, looks over at the dog, the up at the wall at the far end of the room.
Hanging on the wall are a couple of framed photographs of Marty and Abby, taken a long time ago.
Staring at the pictures. He looks back down at the pool t

Abby is sitting on a large double bed. She puts aside ano purse, rises and crosses the room hurriedly, and pushes b the sliding doors of a long wardrobe closet. The upper sh is lined with handbags--fifteen or twenty of them. She gr the first one, looks in, tosses it aside; grabs the secon looks--and stops.
Inside the purse, a small pearl-handled gun.
Ray is now standing in front of the pictures on the wall, looking from one to the next.
A picture of Abby and Marty standing together on a Gulf b Marty is wearing a long velour beach robe, Abby is in a  swimming suit. Ray's hand enters frame. He traces a finge down her leg.
His head cocked to the side. After a moment his eyes shif

Of Marty's face. He is staring into the camera, at whoeve took the picture. His head is thrown back slightly; he is laughing. From offscreen in the quiet room we hear a static hum and then Abby's voice over an intercom.
Ray...?
He turns from the photograph and walks to an intercom spe next to the mounted moose's head. He presses the speaker  button.
Yeah...
He idly takes his unlit cigarette and sticks it in the mo mouth.
...You get what you wanted?
Yeah. Let's get out of here.

We are looking across a dark, high-ceilinged foyer toward the front door. Ray leans against the doorjamb, in silhou in the open doorway. He is facing a curved staircase that descends into the foyer. Abby appears at the second-floor landing and starts down the stairs.
Why d'you wanna leave all this?
You kidding? I don't wanna leave all  this, I just wanna leave Marty...
As she reaches the bottom of the stairs:
...Drive me to a motel?
You can stay at my place, I'll drop  you there.
Where... where you going?
See a guy.
(nervously) Don't go to the bar, Ray. I know  him, that ain't a good idea.
I just gotta see a guy.
The crowd has thinned out. Meurice and Debra are in the  foreground. Ray enters from the street and makes his way over to them
Howdy stranger.
Meurice. Sorry I didn't show last  night.

Wasn't too busy. You missed a good  one, though. This white guy walks in  about one o'clock, asks if we have a  discount for alcoholics... I tell  him to get lost, but Marty's sitting  here listening and I can tell he's  thinking that maybe it ain't such a  bad idea...
He pours Debra another drink and starts to set one up for Ray.
...Ray, this is Debra. She's a  geologist. That's the theory of rocks.
Ray nods at Debra.
Is Marty here?
Not here tonight. Wasn't here last  night. He's especially not back in  his office.
(leaving) Thanks Meurice.
For what?
Marty is sitting on the stoop that descends from his back office to a graveled back parking lot; he is framed in th open doorway of his brightly lit office. He stares fixedl at something offscreen.
In the middle distance a huge incinerator operates full b Orange flames lick out the sides; white smoke billows out the top. Two figures in silhouette are chucking garbage i through a large gate.
Behind him, in the office, we see the door from the bar o and Ray entering.
Marty?
Marty looks over his shoulder, then back toward the furna Ray descends the stoop and stands in front of him.
...Well...? What?
Marty stares past Ray across the parking lot.
What "what"?
Am I fired? You wanna hit me? What?
I don't particularly want to talk to  you.
Well... if you're not gonna fire me  I might as well quit.
Fine. Suit yourself. (still staring fixedly  at the furnace) ...Having a good time?
Ray tenses. There is a pause.
...I don't like this kind of talk.
Marty still stares at the furnace.
Then what'd you come here for?
(no more conciliation) You owe me for two weeks.
Marty shakes his head.
Nope. She's an expensive piece of  ass...
He finally looks up at Ray.
...You get a refund though, if you  tell me who else she's been sluicing.
I want that money. If you wanna tell  me something, fine--
What're you, a fucking marriage  counselor?
Ray breaks into a strained half-smile. Marty grins humorlessly back, mimicking Ray's smile.

What're you smiling at--I'm a funny  guy, right, I'm an asshole? No, no,  that's not what's funny. What's funny  is her. What's funny is that I had  you two followed because, if it isn't  you, she's been sleeping with someone  else...
He grabs a knee in each hand and leans forward, still loo at Ray. He is becoming only slightly more animated.
...What's really going to be funny  is when she gives you that innocent  look and says, What're you talking  about, Ray, I haven't done anything  funny...
He leans back again.
...But the funniest thing to me right  now is that you think she came back  here for you--*that's* what's funny.

Ray moves forward and Marty's eyes follow him as he  approaches. Marty's smile abruptly turns to a look of  apprehension. Ray enters frame and brushes past Marty as walks up the stoop, and crosses the back office toward th bar. Marty relaxes, and his gaze returns to the furnace.
...Come on this property again and  I'll be forced to shoot you...
Ray opens the door to the bar and shuts it softly behind  him.
...Fair notice.
At the cut the music and all other bar noise drops out. W hear only the rhythmic whir of the fan. We tilt down from the ceiling fan to frame Marty, tilted back in his desk c staring up at the fan.
Marty...
Meurice is standing in the door to the bar. Far behind hi we can see Debra waiting in the dimly lit, deserted bar.
...I thought you were dead. Going  home?
No. I think I'll stay right here in  hell.
(turning to leave) Kind of a bleak point of view there,  isn't it Marty?
Meurice...
Meurice pauses in the doorway.
...I don't want that asshole near my  money. I don't even want him in the  bar.
We get a lot of assholes in here,  Marty.

Meurice and Debra can be heard leaving the bar. Marty loo down at the telephone in front of him on the desk, then p up the receiver and dials. He tilts back in the chair and stares back up at the ceiling.
The ceiling fan, turning slowly.

location: RAY'S BUNGALOW FROM INSIDE RAY'S CAR

text: In the foreground Ray sits behind the wheel of his parked car, slumped back against the seat. He is staring at his story bungalow, in which a couple of lights are burning.  Inside we can faintly hear his telephone ringing. It rings for a long time.
Abby's hand enters frame, hesitates, then after another r picks up.
Hello?
The is no answer. From the other end we hear only the rhy whir of a ceiling fan.
Marty listens. He says nothing, still tilted back in his  chair, staring at the ceiling.
Abby listens. She shifts the phone to her other ear, list hard to the sound of the fan. There is another long pause
...Marty?
The phone goes dead just as we hear the front door openin Abby looks up as she cradles the phone. Ray is standing in the doorway.
Who was it?
What?
On the phone. Was it for you?
I don't know, he didn't say anything.
Uh-huh. So how do you know it was a  he?
(smiling) You got a girl--am I screwing  something up by being here?
Ray leans against the door and folds his arms, watching A
No, am I?
Abby looks at him, puzzled. After an uncomfortable pause:
...I can find a place tomorrow, then  I'll be outta your hair.
If that's what you want to do, then  you oughta do it. You, uh... you  want the bed or the couch?
Abby shifts uneasily, looking at Ray.
Well... the couch would be all  right...
You can sleep on the bed if you want.
Well... I'm not gonna put you out of  your bed...
You wouldn't be putting me out.
...Well, I'd be okay in here--
Ray walks toward the bedroom.
Okay.
Still tilted back in his chair, Marty stares glumly at th ceiling. The bar itself is completely still except the  rhythmic whir of the fan.

Turning slowly. We tilt down from the fan to frame Abby,  lying under a sheet on Ray's couch, staring up at the fan the darkened living room. The room is still. We hear only the whir of the fan and the distant sound of crickets. Ab turns her head, looking offscreen.
A ray of light slants up the hallway from the direction o the bedroom. The light is snapped off, leaving the hallwa in darkness. We hear a faint cough and the creaking of  bedsprings.
Ray lies in bed, staring at the ceiling.
Abby sits up. She stands and walks across the moonlit roo toward the hallway. We pull her back down the hall toward the bedroom. She pauses in the bedroom doorway and looks  down toward the bed.
Ray in bed, his eyes closed.
We pull her as she enters the room, then tilt down with h as she hesitantly sits on the edge of the bed.
Close shot, Ray asleep.
Framed against a moonlit window from the shoulders up. There is a long pause. Ray's hand enters frame and pulls Abby down out of frame  onto the bed. We hold on the moonlit window.

Through the window the slow dissolve gradually defines th front lawn and the street beyond in the flat pre-dawn lig Abby rises into frame and quietly gets out of bed. The ca tracks behind her as she walks up the hallway into the li room. We follow her across the living room and move into a clos shot on her hand as she reaches into her purse and withdr a small plastic compact.
She flips open the compact, then, hearing something, look up, squinting across the room.
In the shadows at the far end of the room we can just see two pointed ears and a glittering pair of eyes. The Germa shepherd is panting softly.
As she peers into the shadows, her face reflected in the  mirror of the open compact.
Opal--
In the mirror something moves just behind her. Abby start to turn. Marty's hand clamps over her mouth from behind. His other hand circles her waist. Abby struggles.
(quietly) Lover-boy oughta lock his door...
Marty's hand drops from her waist to her thighs and slide under the robe.
...Lotta nuts out there.

Still holding her from behind, Marty forces her down on h knees. Abby's cries are muffled by the hand clamped over mouth. Marty shoots a glance down the dark hallway. There no movement. Abby's hand is groping forward out of frame.
She upsets it. The contents spill out, among them a small pearl-handled revolver. Her hand gropes for the gun.
Marty yanks her to her feet, looking down the hallway.
Let's do it outside...
He is dragging her to the front door.
...in nature.
He pushes her through the screen door.

The neighborhood is deserted and still. The streetlamps a still on. Marty and Abby stumble down the front stoop ont the lawn. His hand is still clamped over her mouth. She reaches up, grabs a finger, and bends it back. We hear the bone snap. Marty screams. His hand drops. His other hand cuffs her o the side of the head, spinning her around. Marty is now clutching his broken finger with his good ha Abby kicks him in the groin. He sinks to his knees, drops forward on one hand, and vom
Ray is coming out the door, hitching up his pants. In his right hand he hold Abby's pearl-handled revolver.
Slowly gets to his feet, looking at Ray.
She has backed away from Marty and now stands on the lawn breathing heavily. She looks from Ray to Marty.

Backing toward his car, a Cadillac parked at curbside, st looking at Ray. He turns to get into the car. The German shepherd lopes across the lawn and takes a cle leap into the car through the open window on the passenge side. Marty turns the ignition. The engine coughs and dies. He  tries again; it starts. The car roars up the street.
Watching the car. He looks at Abby.
Still panting. Up the street we can hear Marty's car  alternately racing and stopping, shifting in and out of g His engine rumble starts to grow louder again.
Like to have seen his face when he  found the dead end.
In the background we see Marty's car roar by in the oppos direction.

Moving past a row of cars parked on an overlook near the of the mountain. Below we can see the lights of the city Austin. The lot is littered with beer cans. We hear the s of rock music coming from various car radios. Several  teenagers lean against cars drinking beer; inside the car we can see the vague forms of others.
Hey mister, how'd you break your  pussyfinger?
His friends laugh.
Ignoring the laughter as he walks past the cars, apparent looking for someone. His right index finger is taped up i an aluminum splint.

At the end of a row of cars we see a green Volkswagon bug Leaning against the hood is Visser, still dressed in his  rumpled yellow suit. He is smoking a cigarette, talking t sixteen-year-old girl in shorts and a tube top. When he  notices Marty:
(to the girl) Sorry sweetheart, my date is here...
The girl drifts off. Marty enters frame and Visser turns him.
...She saw me rolling a cigarette  and thought it was marijuana. (he laughs) I guess she thought I was a swinger.
Visser open the back door of the car. Marty ignores the  invitation, walks around to the front on the passenger si and gets in.

As Visser gets into the driver's seat. A small topless do is suspended from the rearview mirror. Visser gives it a  tap. As it swings back and forth two small lights, one be each breast, blink on and off.
Idnat wild?
Both men sit watching the doll intently. Finally Marty reaches up and stops its swinging with the  rounded end of his splint. Visser eyes the splint.
(genially) Stick your finger up the wrong  person's ass?
Marty is silent, but Visser is in a good mood.

You know a friend of mine broke his  hand a while back. Put in a cast.  Very next day he takes a fall,  protects his bad hand, falls on his  good one, breaks that too. So now  he's got two busted flippers and I  say to him "Creighton, I hope your  wife loves you. 'Cause for the next  five weeks you cannot wipe your own  goddamn ass..."
Overcome by laughter. Finally:
...That's the test, ain't it? Test  of true love--
Got a job for you.
(settling down) ...Well, if the pay's right and it's  legal I'll do it.
It's not strictly legal.
Visser shrugs, lights up another cigarette with his  fraternally inscribed lighter and drops the lighter onto dashboard.
If the pay's right I'll do it.
It's, uh... it's in reference to  that gentleman and my wife. The more  I think about it the more irritated  I get.
Yeah? Well how irritated are you?
Marty doesn't answer. Finally Visser laughs.
...Gee, I'm sorry to hear that. Can  you tell me what you want me to do  or is it a secret?
Listen, I'm not--this isn't a joke  here.
Visser eyes him, still smiling. Finally he shrugs.
You want me to kill 'em.
I didn't say that. (a pause) Well?
Well what?
What do you think?
You're an idiot.
Marty's shoulders slump. He seems less tense, almost reli
So, uh... this wouldn't interest  you.
I didn't say that. All I said was  you're an idiot. Hell, you been  thinking about it so much it's driving  you simple.
They are staring at each other.
Ten thousand dollars I'll give you.
Visser laughs again.
I'm supposed to do a murder--two  murders--and just trust you not to  go simple on me and do something  stupid. I mean real stupid. Now why  should I trust you?
For the money.
(sobering) The money. Yeah. That's a right smart  of money...
He turns and gazes out the window.
...In Russia they make only fifty  cents a day.
He falls silent again, still staring out the window In the closeness of the car Marty is starting to sweat.
(hoarsely) ...There's a big--
(abruptly) I want you to go fishing.
...What?
Go down to Corpus for a few days.  Get yourself noticed. I'll give you  a call when it's done... You just  find a way to cover that money.

Marty is slumped in his seat, not responding to the fact  that Visser has just ended the conversation. Finally he rouses himself and gets out of the car, leavin Visser staring at the door he has left open behind him. After a moment we hear Marty's footsteps approaching agai and he leans back into the open door with an afterthought
I'll take care of the money, you  just make sure those bodies aren't  found... There's a...
These words are difficult to say.
...If you want, there's a big  incinerator behind my place...
The two men look at each other. Marty leaves. After a mom Visser leans over to grab the handle of the still open do
(under his breath) Sweet Jesus, you are disgusting.
The door slams.

The apartment is dark. We are looking across a shadowy fl towards a large window, through which cold blue street li shines. Through the window we can see the facade of the  building across the street; we are three or four floors u We can hear the animated, accented voice of an Hispanic w approaching the apartment from the hallway behind us.
--big windows, paneleen and  everytheen. So you want, like your  own place? Like a Town House?

A crack of light shoots across the floor as we hear the  apartment door open behind us. A figure enters frame. As crosses into the shaft of light we see that it is Abby. S moves across the dark apartment, in silhouette against th window.
No one will bother you here, sweetie--

An overhead light is switched on and the room is bathed i light. Several feet from Abby, an old man in a dirty  undershirt is asleep on a cot. Abby starts. The old man grumbles, slowly sits up, squints. With the light, the window behind Abby has become a mirro of the entire room, in which we now see the matronly Land standing by the wall switch. The Landlady roars at the old man in Spanish. The man glo at her. The Landlady looks back at Abby.
(cheerful again) I show you around.
We follow Abby as she accompanies the landlady back into short hallway-entrance foyer. Abby glances back at the ol man.
Are you sure this is... Are you sure  this apartment is vacant?... Mrs.  Esteves?
The Landlady laughs cheerfully.
Oh yes...
She gestures to a kitchen alcove on the left.
...That's the kitchen...
She turns and throws a few more barbs in Spanish back tow the old man, then opens a door on the right side of the f and enters the bathroom.
...This is the bathroom...
She flushes the toilet.
...The toilet works and everytheen...
She bustles out of the bathroom and takes the two short s back into the main room. She gestures expansively.
...And here we are back in the liveen  room.
She gives one vigorous stomp.
...Good floors. Gas heat.
She points.
...That's Mr. Garcia.

The old man is now sitting on the edge of the bed, smokin cigarette, looking for a place to put the ash. The Landla snaps at him again in Spanish, and is again cheerful as s turns back to address Abby.
...I was just esplaineen to him that  he moved out of here yesterday...
She walks to the apartment door.
...You look around. Don't mind Mr.  Garcia; he use do be my brother-in- law.
She walks out and shuts the door. The room is quiet.
Staring at the door. She looks at Mr. Garcia, looks nervo around the apartment. She looks back at Mr. Garcia.
Staring vacantly at Abby. He blows a stream of smoke acro the room. The ash falls off his cigarette.

Hunched over the public address microphone in his small  cubicle of exhortation, is the middle-aged strip-bar bark Years of service in the bar have left his exhortations  depressingly bereft of conviction.
How 'bout it, gentlemen, let's show  out appreciation for Lorraine up  there, a registered nurse from Bolton,  Texas, how 'bout it gentlemen, yeah...

Meurice is one of a line of men sitting at the bar, all  looking intently at the same point off left. All of the m except Meurice are conservatively dressed and apparently  well-to-do. An audio loop is blaring a bump-and-grind ver of "Yellow Rose of Texas," punctuated by the crash of cym and the thumping of toms. Abby enters and sits into an empty chair next to Meurice.
Looks like the state legislature is  out of session.
Meurice continues to stare intently off.
I thought this is where they met.

All of the heads at the bar start to swivel, including  Meurice's. A couple of patrons hurriedly snatch their dri off the bar. In the extreme foreground a stripper dances on the top of the bar into frame. We crop her just above her white high heeled cowboy boots and her bare calves. The conversation continues with Abby looking at Meurice, Meurice and everyone else at the bar looking up at a poin somewhere above the stripper's calves.
Listen Meurice, you're gonna help me  with a problem.
I am?
The stripper drops a white leatherette vest onto the bar the foreground. The audience cheers.
You're gonna keep an eye on Marty  and Ray, make sure nothing happens.
It won't?
Two sheriff-star pasties drop onto the bar. The audience  cheers.
...Ever occur to you, Abby, that  maybe I'm the wrong person to ask?
Into his microphone.
Let's not sit on our wallets,  gentlemen. Lorraine is up there  dancing her heart out, and if you  let that cash money set on your hip,  you might just as well be broke...
She is rising to leave; he is still staring off.
Thanks, Meurice.
Any time. But you don't have to worry  about a thing for a while. Marty  went down to Corpus yesterday.
An old-west gunbelt hits the bar. The audience roars.
Into his microphone.
And remember, gentlemen, we're always  here, two to two, A.M. to P.M., three  hundred and sixty-four days and  Christmas, God willing and the creek  don't rise...
The room is dark. We are looking across the room toward a moonlit window. Beyond, across the lawn, the lamplit stre is empty. Suddenly Abby sits bolt upright into frame from the bed b
He's in the house.
Offscreen we hear Ray stirring in bed.
What's the matter?
Abby twists around to look down at him.
I could've sworn I heard something.
Door's locked. Nothing there.
He pulls her down out of frame and we hold on the window the empty lamplit street. Then Abby rises back into frame in silhouette against the window, looking down at Ray.
I knew it. 'Cause we wouldn't have  heard anything if it was him. He's  real careful. Fact is, he's anal.
...Huh?
Yeah, he told me once himself. He  said to me...
She taps herself on the forehead.
..."In here, Abby. In here... I'm  anal."
Looking up at Abby.
(yawning) ...Well I'll be damned.
I couldn't believe it either...
Framed against the window, looking down at Ray.
...Me on the other hand, I got lots  of personality...
She drops down onto the bed out of frame. The camera hold on the window through which we see the empty lamplit stre
Marty always said I had too much.  'Course he was never big on  personality...
She rises back up into frame, in silhouette against the  window.
...He sent me to a psychiatrist to  see if he could calm me down some.
Yeah? What happened?
Psychiatrist said I was the healthiest  person he'd ever met, so Marty fired  him.
(sleepily) ...I don't know if you can fire a  psychiatrist, exactly.
Well, I didn't see him anymore, I'll  tell you that much.
His eyes half-closed.
Uh-huh.
I said, Marty, how come you're anal  and I gotta go to the psychiatrist?
What'd he say?
Framed against the window.
Nothing. He's like you, he doesn't  say much.
(murmuring) Thanks.
Except when he doesn't say things  they're usually nasty.
...Mm-hmm.
When you don't they're usually nice.
...You ever get tired?
Huh? Oh, yeah, I guess. Mm-hmm.

Ray's hand rises into frame and coaxes Abby back down ont the bed, revealing, through the window, a green Volkswago now parked at curbside on the lamplit street. We hear the rustle of sheets. As we hold on the window, we begin to hear the faint, dis sound of metal scraping against metal.

We track down the dark hallway into the living room. As t camera advances the sound of the scraping becomes louder. We are moving across the living room up to the front door the bungalow. The scraping is louder still as we finally  frame on a close shot of the doorknob, which is jiggling  ever so slightly. We hear a click as the lock finally releases. The door swings slowly open, revealing a man's hand on th outside doorknob. We follow the hand as the man advances  slowly and quietly across the living room. Abby's purse comes into frame, sitting on a bureau; next it is a large tote bag. The hand rummages through the tot bag briefly, then the purse. The man withdraws Abby's pea handled revolver. He breaks it open.
It is Visser. As we hear a click offscreen, his face glow dim orange.

His right holds the revolver, cylinder open, inside the p His left holds his cigarette lighter as he inspects the  chamber. Three of the holes glint silver, the other three are black--empty. We hear the faint creaking of bedsprings.

Visser cocks his head, listening, and looks down the hall He takes a couple of quiet steps across the living room a as the camera tracks up to him, opens the back door of th bungalow. We follow him outside onto the lawn.

We track behind him as he rounds the corner of the house approaches the open window to Ray's bedroom. He slows, mo more cautiously, then sinks to his knees under the window As he reaches into his breast pocket the camera continues tracking up to and over him, finally framing his POV thro the window. On the bed inside we can dimly see Abby and Ray, asleep. We have been hearing a faint rumble, becoming louder and  louder as if approaching from a distance. Just as the rum becomes deafening a sudden bright flash of light illumina the room, seeming to polarize the image of Abby and Ray i bed, and we:

A huge truck roars by on the street behind Visser, and wi it the deafening rumble recedes. It is a painfully bright day. Visser stands sweating in the phone booth with the  receiver pressed to his ear. We hear the phone ringing at the other end. Finally, it is picked up.
Hello.
Marty?
Yeah. Is it...
Ya catch any fish?
...What?
Ya catch any fish?
Yeah...
...What kind of fish?
Listen, what is it? Is it done?
Visser forces a chuckle.
...Yessir, you owe me some money.
Being plopped down onto Marty's desk.

Visser sits facing the desk. He lights himself a cigarett and sets the lighter down on the desk in front of him. Ma settles, fidgeting, into the chair behind it. The bar is quiet, shut down. We hear only the whir of a f somewhere offscreen. Marty and Visser are lit by a lamp o the desk between them. Light streams into the room from a bathroom in the background. Visser is looking at the dead fish.
(dully) They look good.
Marty half-rises from his seat and picks up one of the  strings.
Want a couple?
He drops them on Visser's side of the desk. Visser's head draws back: he was only being polite.
Just the ten thousand'll be fine.
Got something to show me first?
Visser hands a 9 x 12 envelope across the desk. Marty sta at it for a moment, then quickly bends back the flap and  takes out an 8 x 10 photograph.
It is a black-and-white shot of Abby and Ray in Ray's bed The sheet that partially covers them is pocked with three dark bullet holes and is stained with blood.
Staring dully down at the picture.
Dead, huh?
So it would seem.
Visser is pushing the fish away from his side of the desk with the eraser end of a pencil.
What did you...
Still looking at the picture. He traces the outline of Ab body with his finger.
...What did you do with the bodies?
It's taken care of. The less you  know about it the better.
Jesus, I don't believe it...
Marty slips the picture back into its 9 x 12 envelope. Hi face is pale.
...I think I'm gonna be sick.
He rises and heads for the bathroom, still clutching the  envelope.
As his eyes follow Marty's exit. The bathroom door doesn' close all the way; a narrow shaft of light slices the off from the bare bulb in the bathroom.
I'll want that picture back...
He turns to look across the desk.
The standing safe behind the desk.
Still looking at the safe. Beads of sweat have popped out his forehead. He fans himself with his cowboy hat.
...and you did say somethin' about  some money.
We hear a toilet flush offscreen.
As he reenters the office.
Your money, yeah.
Visser stares dully down at the desktop.
Something I got to ask you, Marty.  I've been very very careful. Have  you been very very careful?
Of course.
Nobody knows you hired me?

Marty is hunched over the open safe, still holding the  envelope. Blocking Visser's view of the safe with his bod he slides the picture of Abby's and Ray's corpses from un the envelope into the safe, then withdraws two packets of money.
Don't be absurd, I wasn't about to  tell anyone...
He shuts the safe and spins the dial.
...This is an illicit romance--we've  got to trust each other to be  discreet...
He walks across the room and throws the money and the env down on the desk.
...For richer, for poorer.
Visser looks from the money down at his hands. They are  sweating.
Don't say that. Your marriages don't  work out so hot...
He wipes his hands on his pants.
...How did you cover the money?
Marty sits and props his booted feet up on the desk.
It's taken care of. The less you  know about it the better.
He smiles.
...I just made a call about that.  It'll look fine.
(shaking his head) I must've gone money simple. This  kind of murder...
He nods toward the envelope on the desk.
...it's too damn risky.
Then you shouldn't have done it.  Can't have it both ways.
He pushes the money across the desk with his boot.
...Count it if you want.
(reaching into his  coat) Nah, I trust ya.
His hand comes out with a gun pointing at Marty and--BAM- fires, an orange lick of flame spurting from the gun. Both men sit frozen. Visser's hand is the only thing that moved.
Staring at Visser. After the gun blast we hear only the whir of the fan.
Staring at Marty.
His eyes are now shut. Otherwise he hasn't moved. A blood stain is growing on the front of his shirt.

The two face each other across the desk. Visser's gun is  still trained on Marty. After a moment Visser starts fanning himself again with h cowboy hat. The only movement in the frame is the slow ba and-forth of the yellow hat, rhythmically in and out of s as it catches and loses the light from the desk lamp. The is a long pause. Finally one of Marty's feet slips from the desk and hits floor with a THUD. Visser lays the gun on the desk.
As he reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a  handkerchief. He wipes his forehead, then picks up the gu and wipes it off. He leans down with the gun.
As Visser places it deliberately on the floor near the de It is Abby's pearl-handled revolver.

As Visser straightens up in the foreground. From our head angle shooting across the desk we can see the bright meta glint of Visser's cigarette lighter underneath the dead f Visser's hands move over the near part of the desk, picki up the money and the 9 x 12 picture envelope.
As Visser turns from the desk and walks across the room o of frame. We hear the back door opening.
Who looks stupid now.

The door slams shut. The only sound is the whir of the fan. A pause. The camer tracks slowly forward, tilting down to keep Marty and the desktop centered in frame. As the camera moves the noise the fan grows louder. When Marty's body and the desk are  directly beneath us, the blades of the ceiling fan cut ac the immediate foreground and effect a:

It is completely still. We are looking from the bar, acro the dark empty floor, toward the pebbled windows at the f of the building that catch a hard blue light from the  streetlamps outside. The jukebox in the middle distance g in the darkness. A pair of headlights catches the pebbled glass and grows  brighter as we hear a car pull up to the bar and stop. We hear a car door open and shut, then the sound of feet on  gravel. A huge shadow appears on the pebbled glass as the figure crosses in front of the headlights. The man tries door, finds it locked, and walks back in front of the  headlights to cup his hands at a window. He walks back to the door, and a moment later it swings open--framing him the doorway in silhouette. We follow him as he moves across the floor, behind the ba and up to the cash register. He switches on a small  fluorescent light clamped to the top of the cash register It is Ray. He punches a key and the register rings open. He lifts up the empty cash drawer and takes some papers from undernea it.
As he flips through the papers; bills, receipts, no money
As he finishes flipping through the papers.
(muttering) Damn...
He slips them back under the cash drawer and slams the  register shut. Turning from the register he glances aroun the bar, the pauses, noticing something.
Light is spilling out from under the door to Marty's offi
As he starts across the floor to Marty's office.
Marty...
He reaches the door and knocks sharply. No answer. He tur the knob.
Marty...

The door is locked. We hear the muffled whir of the ceili fan inside. A pause. Ray withdraws a ring of keys from his pocket and uses one on the door. The door swings open. Over his shoulder we see Marty, still at his desk, his ba to us. On foot is still propped on the desk.
What's the matter, you deaf?

No answer. Ray stumbles toward Marty. He stumbles slightly and we hear the sharp blast of a gun and the sound of something metallic skating across the fl Ray, startled, steadies himself against the desk, then st Marty.
There is a dark pool of blood under Marty's chair.
He looks back up at Marty, then walks behind his chair an throws a wall switch. The room is bathed in light. His ey still on Marty, Ray crosses behind the desk.
The camera moves in a slow arc around the back of Marty's motionless head.
Still moving. He looks away from Marty, scans the floor. gets down on his hands and knees and peers under the safe
There is a glinting silver circle in the darkness under t safe. It is the business end of the revolver that Ray hal stumbled over, half-kicked.
Still on his hands and knees. He reaches in and we hear a rattle as he gropes under the safe. He withdraws the gun, looks at it.
It is Abby's revolver.
For a long moment he doesn't move. Then, slowly, he start to get up.

The desk, Marty behind it, Ray straightening behind him. looks from the gun to Marty, slowly sets the gun down on desk. A pause. He begins to hoist Marty from the chair. There is noise from the bar, as of someone entering. Ray reacts.
Separating the bar and back office. Ray hurries to it.
Marty?
Footsteps approach the door.
He turns it gently. The bolt clicks shut.
Meurice's footsteps draw nearer.
Marty, ya home?

There is a rap at the door; Ray stands frozen. The doorkn rattles. Ray reaches out compulsively to grab it, but sto himself before actually touching it. Now Meurice's footsteps can be heard going casually back  into the bar. We hold on Ray's rigidly set face.
What day is it today, Angie?
Tuesday.
Tuesday is ladies' night.
What?
Tuesday night is ladies' night. All  your drinks are free.

We hear a record drop on the jukebox and a Motown song bl Ray crosses to Marty's chair and takes off his nylon  windbreaker. He stoops down and tries to mop up the pool blood with his windbreaker. This isn't going to work. He rises and walks over to the bathroom, the windbreaker  dripping blood.
The song continues faintly in the background. The faucet turned on and Ray's hand enters frame, holding a dirty wh towel under the stream of water.

The song continues in the background. Ray's hand enters f holding the balled-up towel. His windbreaker is wrapped  inside. The camera follows as he pushes it across the tra of dripped blood to the pool of blood under Marty's chair
He still has not moved. Ray rises into frame and takes hi under the armpits. He notices something on the desk in fr of him.
Ray's hand enters frame and picks it up.
Ray's hand enters frame and slips the gun into Marty's po Marty is hoisted up.

location: BACK OF THE BAR / PARKING LOT

text: Ray appears in the doorway. The music from the bar, thoug fainter, can still be heard. There are three or four wooden steps going down from the  back door to the small gravel parking lot in back. Ray ba down the stairs; Marty's feet THUMP-THUMP-THUMP down the  stairs after him. The rear door of Ray's car is open. Ray heaves in Marty's torso. Marty's legs rest on the ground outside the car. R takes an ankle in each hand and pushes.
As he shuts the door. He looks up across the parking lot.
The incinerator belching fire and smoke. We hear its dist roar over the bar song. We hear the car door slam.

We are looking down on Ray's car as the camera tracks beh it towards the incinerator. At the cut the roar of the  incinerator is suddenly louder. It grows louder still as approach it. Ray's car draws even with the incinerator without slowing stopping. The wadded-up towel is chucked out of his windo into the fire. We hold on the fire as Ray's car rolls on of frame.

As he drives down a deserted country highway. We hear the rhythmic sound of the wheels clomping over asphalt. The r is broadcasting a fundamentalist's sermon, periodically  interrupted by static. Ray is sweating.

--so there were three signs, the  second of which is Famine, this famine  which I have already pointed out is  devastatin' Africa and the Indian  subcontinent. And the third of these  signs is earthquakes. Now I don't  know why he threw that in but if you  talk to a geologist, and I've talked  to many, he'll tell you that  earthquake activity--
Ray twists around and looks in the back seat.
Marty is lying inert.
--has increased almost eighty percent  in the past two years, and what's  more, in two years' time we'll be  experiencin' what's knows as the  Jupiter Effect--
He looks back at the road. A car roars by.

--wherein all the planets of the  known universe will be aligned up  causin' an incredible buildup of  destructive gravitational force. Now  in Matthew Chapter Six, Verse Eighteen  the Lord out and tells us that these  are the signs by which we shall know  that He is at our door. There are  many good people disagree with me,  but it's my belief that this  Antichrist is alive today and livin'  somewhere in Europe, in that ten- nation alliance I spoke of, bein'  groomed for his task--
Ray switches off the radio. We hear the sound of faint, labored breathing.
His jaw tightens. He whips his head toward the back seat. His head snaps forward again and he slams on the brakes. The car screeches to a halt.

As Ray's door flies open. He is bolting from the car. The camera, at waist level, tracks toward him as he races out into the field that abuts the highway. Fifty yards in he finally stops, panting, framed from a l angle. His breath vaporizes in the crisp night air. We he only his breath and the chirring of crickets. He is looki back toward the road.
Standing abandoned on the shoulder of the deserted highwa Its headlights cast a lonely beam up the road. No movemen
His panting slows. He is in a cold sweat. After a long mo he starts walking slowly, reluctantly, back toward the ca
Toward the car. Still no sign of movement.
He slows as he draws up to the back of the car. He looks the back window.
It is empty. The door on the highway side is ajar.
No reaction. He walks around the back of the car onto the highway. He  looks up the road.
Marty is crawling up the road on his hands and knees, lea a trail of blood. The headlights of Ray's car give a  fantastically long shadow.
Still no reaction. He gets into the driver's seat and sta through the windshield as he gropes for the ignition key.
Marty, crawling.
He throws the car into drive, looks at his target, thinks decides. He pulls the key out of the ignition and goes ar to the trunk of the car. He opens it and pulls out a shov

From in front. The headlights glare behind him. His breat vaporizes. In the background Ray is walking toward him,  dragging the shovel, which scrapes along the asphalt. As moves into the foreground and turns to face Marty only hi lower legs and the shovel are in frame. The shovel rises out of frame.
Both hands hold the shovel tensed over his shoulder. He s down at Marty. A long pause. We hear a distant rumble.
Inches away from Marty. Marty's hand slides forward and w around one of Ray's ankles.
He shudders. He adjusts his grip on the shovel. The rumble grows louder.
He jerks his foot away, breaking Marty's grasp.
Looks up from Marty. The rumble grows louder.
Headlight beams, although not yet the headlights themselv are visible a long way down the road.
Staring down the road. Finally he lowers the shovel, walk back to the car and throws it viciously into the trunk, w back up into the foreground and stoops down.

As Ray grabs him under the armpits and starts dragging hi back to the car. Just before Ray heaves him into the back seat, Marty coughs weakly. A fine spray of blood comes ou with the cough. The engine rumble is quite loud now.
As he slams the back door shut. He presses himself agains the side of the car. Headlights glare over him; the truck roars by just behind him.

Sudden quiet at the cut. We are looking at Ray's car in  profile, parked in the middle of a deserted field. From  offscreen we hear the sound of a shovel biting into earth We track laterally down the car, along the beam of its  headlights, to finally frame Ray as he climbs out of the  shallow grave he has just finished digging. He plants the shovel and walks back to the car.
The grave in the middle background; the car's headlights  beyond it. Ray is dragging Marty toward the grave. He dumps him in.
As Marty thumps to the bottom, face up.
As he bends over to pick up the shovel, dripping sweat. W hear the shovel biting into earth.
Ray, in the foreground, pitches the first shovelful of ea onto Marty. Marty moves slightly.
As he pauses, looking down into the grave. He stoops down and resumes shoveling, bobbing in and out of frame as he  hurls dirt into the grave.
As Ray shovels, Marty is moving under the loose dirt. A f inarticulate noise comes from the grave. Almost imperceptibly, Marty's right arm starts to rise.

Ray stands on the lip of the grave, hunched over his shov crisply illuminated by the headlights. In the shadowy  foreground Marty's arm rises, extended toward Ray. He is  clutching Abby's gun in his splint-fingered hand.
As he straightens up and stands motionless, expressionles watching Marty, making no attempt to get out of the way.
The gun extended into the foreground. His index finger  splinted, he slides his middle finger over the trigger of the gun.
Watching.
The gun trembling in the foreground. His knuckle whitens  over the trigger. The trigger releases and we hear the dull click of an emp chamber.
Staring blankly down at Marty.

Of Marty's gun hand as Ray slowly sinks down on the lip o the grave, bracing himself with the shovel. His hand reac for Marty's. Marty squeezes off two more empty chambers.  Ray's hand slowly closes over the barrel of the gun. As he pulls, the gun slides from Marty's fingers.
Biting into the earth.
Furiously shoveling dirt into the grave.
Marty barely visible under the dirt.
Shoveling, panting.
Half full.
Working furiously. His breath comes in short gasps.
It is filled. Ray is packing down the earth, slamming the shovel furiously against the bare patch of earth.
Being slammed down against the earth. Again and again.

The staccato beat of the shovel slamming against earth dr out at the cut. There is perfect quiet. The sun is just  peeping over the horizon. In the foreground Ray is sittin in the open door of his car, smoking a cigarette. His gaz is fixed on a spot offscreen.
A house. Quite near by. The house and its perfect green rectangle of lawn are set incongruously in the middle of the open field.

Staring, without emotion. He takes one last, fierce drag on the cigarette, then fli it away. He takes the shovel, walks over to the grave and stares at it for several seconds, shovel clasped firmly i both hands. He walks back to the car.

House, car and grave. Ray throws the shovel into the car, gets in, and turns the ignition. The engine coughs weakly and dies. He tries again. Same result. One more time. The engine coughs, sputters, and fires to  life. The car runs over the grave and rattles on across t rutted field towards the highway in the distance.
As Ray drives down the straight empty highway in the flat early-morning light.
Pale and unblinking.
In the distance we see a beat-up white station wagon  approaching. It's headlights wink on, then off again.
He squints at the approaching car.
The car is closer. It's headlights wink again.
His jaw tightens. He stares intently at the car. Then,  abruptly, he looks down at his dashboard.
His headlights are on. Ray's hand enters frame and pushes the knob.
Watching the approaching station wagon. As it passes we c a glimpse of its occupant. He grins and cocks a you-got-i finger at Ray before roaring out of frame.

The station hasn't opened yet. Ray's car, empty, stands a in the lot. Flat prairie stretches to the horizon. No mov in the frame. At the cut we hear the faint sound of a phone ringing thr a receiver. After four or five rings the phone is picked and we begin a slow crane down.
(through phone;  sleepily) Hello?
(present; very hoarsely) Abby... you all right?
Ray?... What time is it?
I don't know. It's early... I love  you.
A beat.
...You all right?
I don't know. I better get off now.
The continuing crane down reveals Ray in a phone booth in the foreground.
Okay, see ya... Thanks, Ray.
Abby--
The phone disconnects.

Her sleeping head on a pillow. Offscreen we hear a door o and shut. A moment later Ray's dirt-caked hand comes into frame and gently brushes a wisp of hair back for Abby's f We hear Ray walk across the apartment and a moment later sound of water running. Abby stirs. She looks offscreen.
Standing in the doorway to the bathroom. He is wiping his hands on a towel.
(sleepily) ...Ray?
You're bad.
Still half asleep, Abby smiles.
...What?
I said you're bad.
There is a long pause. Finally:
(smiling) ...You're bad too.
Ray swings a chair out and sits down behind a table at th far end of the room. He leans back and props his legs up the table. He is staring across the room at Abby.
We're both bad.

As we hear the click of a pull-string the camera is dropp down past an orange safe light, down the length of the st down to a metal darkroom tray where two short strips of  negative are burning. Visser's hand and yellow sleeve cuff (now orange) enter f with an 8 x 10 black-and-white photograph. The photograph dropped into the tray. As it burns we see that it is the  same picture of Abby's and Ray's "corpses" as Visser show Marty, except that in this print the bullet holes and blo are less convincingly brushed in. Another print is dropped into the tray and ignites. In th one we see bullet holes but no blood. A third print is dropped in and ignites. It is the origin undoctored shot of Abby and Ray asleep in bed. Visser's hands enter frame holding the picture-envelope t he took away from Marty's office. Visser rips it in half is about to drop it into the tray, but stops abruptly. There is posterboard, not a photograph, peeking out of th torn envelope. Visser's hands pull the two halves of the placard from th envelope and fit them together. The stenciled 8 x 10 plac says: "All Employees Must Wash Hands Before Resuming Work

Staring at the placard in disbelief. After a moment his hand rises into frame to deposit a  cigarette in his mouth. His hand drops back down, groping a pocket. His hand jumps back into frame, empty; he thumps at his b pockets; he can't find his lighter. He wheels and exits frame. The light snaps off. A door sl shut.
He has dozed off in his chair. Offscreen we hear a door s and his eyes open.
Emerging from the bathroom. Her voice has a flat echo in bare apartment.
Why didn't you get into bed?
(groggy) I didn't think I could sleep. I'm  surprised you could. Are you all  right?
Yeah...
She walks over and sits down on the bed.
...You called me this morning.
Yeah.
Abby looks at him, expecting more. Finally:
...I just wanted to let you know  that everything was all right. I  took care of everything. Now all we  have to do is keep our heads.
...What do you mean?
Ray finally looks directly at her.
I know about it, Abby. I went to the  bar last night.
Abby is looking at him in alarm.
What happened?--Was Meurice there?
Yeah.
He laughs shortly.
...He didn't see me, though. Nobody  saw me.
The chair grates back as he stands up and looks vaguely a the room.
...Is it cold in here?
Abby is looking at him nervously.
Well... what happened?
I cleaned it all up, but that ain't  important...
He starts nervously pacing around the room, looking for  something.
...What's important is what we do  now; I mean we can't go around half- cocked. What we need is some time to  think about this, figure it out...
He moves a packing crate aside, still hunting around the  apartment.
...Anyway, we got some time now. But  we gotta be smart.
Ray--
Abby, never point a gun at anyone  unless you're gonna shoot him. And  when you shoot him you better make  sure he's dead...
Ray's pacing is more agitated as he looks distractedly ar the apartment.
...because if he's not dead he's  gonna get up and try and kill you.
He pauses, seemingly at a total loss.
...That's the only thing they told  us in the service that was worth a  goddamn--Where the hell's my  windbreaker?
What the hell happened, Ray?
Ray is walking to the window. Sunlight streams in around  him.
That ain't important. What's important  is that we did it. That's the only  thing that matters. We both did it  for each other...
He stoops down to look through a pile of clothes by the  window.
...That's what's important.
I don't know what you're talking  about.
Ray's head snaps around. Staring at her he slowly rises t his feet and then remains still.
I... I mean what're you talking about,  Ray? I haven't done anything funny.
...What was that?
Abby, startled, can't contain her agitation anymore.

(rapidly) Ray, I mean you ain't even acting  like yourself. First you call me at  five in the A.M. saying all kinds of  nice things over the telephone and  then you come charging in here scaring  me half to death without even telling  me what it is I'm supposed to be  scared of. I gotta tell you it's  extremely rattling.
We track toward him, isolating him against the window. He perfectly still. For a long time he can't speak.
(quietly) ...Don't lie to me, Abby--
Still worked up.
How can I be lying if I don't even  know--
The ring of the telephone cuts her off. She looks at the  phone, pauses for a moment, then continues, struggling.
...I mean if you and him had a fight  or something, I don't care, as long  as you...
Her voice trails off. The telephone won't stop ringing. Abby and Ray are starin at each other, seemingly oblivious to it. Finally:
...Pick it up.
Still ringing. Abby's hand enters frame and picks it up.
What.

Through the phone we hear only the rhythmic whir of a cei fan. Abby shifts the phone to her other ear, listening ha It is the same sound we heard earlier when she picked up phone at Ray's house. As before, the line clicks dead.
(looking at Ray) ...Welp, that was him.
There is a long moment of silence. Then Ray's voice comes from across the room:
...Who?
Marty.
There is silence again.
Ray shifts in front of the window. He laughs humorlessly. The laugh stops abruptly.
...What's going on with you two?
(quietly) All right...
He starts across the room.
...You can call him back, whoever it  was...
He is heading for the door.
...I'll get out of your way.
He pauses at the foyer and pulls Abby's gun out of his po He sets it on a shelf by the door.
Watching. We hear the door open.
You left your weapon behind.
We hear the door slam shut.

We hear the rhythmic whir of the fan. We tilt down from t ceiling to reveal that we are in the living room of Ray's bungalow. In the foreground Visser sits in a chair with the cradled telephone in his lap, facing the front door, which stands open in the background. The contents of Abby's tote bag l strewn on the bureau next to Visser. Her purse is not the After a moment Visser rouses himself and starts to sweep articles back into the tote bag.

It is dark, lit only by the morning light leaking in arou the drawn blinds. It is a small modern apartment such as sees in large apartment complexes--shag carpeting, built- bar. In the extreme foreground the small red "Power" ligh of a telephone answering machine glows in the darkness. The front door opens in the background, spilling bright  sunlight. Meurice stoops down, picks up two newspapers,  enters, and shuts the door. He walks toward the camera an his hand enters frame in extreme foreground to punch the  rewind button on the machine. His hand leaves frame. A fe pieces of mail are flipped down onto the machine table, p by piece, as the machine rewinds. He reaches down again a hits playback. After a beep:
Hi Meurice, this is Helene, Helene  Trend, and I'm calling 'cause I wanna  know just what the hell that remark  you made about Sylvia's supposed to  mean...
Mail continues to flip down onto the table, piece by piec
...She says you're full of shit and  frankly I believe her. And hey, I  love you too. Sure. Anyway, you better  call me soon because I'm going to  South America tonight--you know,  Uruguay?
Dial tone. Beep.
(barking) Listen asshole, you know who this  is. I just got back from Corpus and  there's a lot of money missing from  the safe...
The mail stops dropping; Marty has Meurice's attention.

...I'm not saying you took it but  the place was your responsibility  and I told you to keep an eye on  your asshole friend. Don't--uh, don't  come to the bar tonight, I've got a  meeting. But tomorrow I want to have  a word with you, and with Ray--if  you can find him.
Dial tone. Beep. Meurice's hand drops into frame.
Meurice, where the hell have you  been? I--
His finger presses the stop button.
Pressing into a dark stain in the upholstery of the back  seat of his car. When he raises it the fingertip is red-- seat still wet with blood.
Looking down at the seat. He backs out of the car and wal up the driveway to his house.

As he comes through the screen door. It bangs shut behind him. As he crosses the living room we see, and he hears,  Meurice's Trans Am pulling up and stopping at the foot of the lawn. Ray turns and looks out the window.
Ray throws it open and hurriedly pulls out the first thin at hand--a sheet. We hear the door of the Trans Am open a slam shut.
Exiting the house as the screen door bangs and shudders b him. He hurries down the walk.
Meurice is rounding the bottom of the lawn and starting u the drive toward the incriminating car. Its back door is  standing ajar.
I hope you're planning on leaving  town.
Reacting to the line as he reaches the car. He bends over throw the sheet over the seat just as Meurice walks up be him.
(his back to Meurice;  arranging the sheet) Got a problem, Meurice?
No, you do, cowboy. You been to the  bar?
Ray is still hunched in the open doorway. He freezes  momentarily in arranging the sheet.
...Why?
You shouldn't have taken the money...
Ray doesn't reply or turn around. Meurice is getting more strident.
...Look at me man, I'm serious. You  broke in the bar and ripped off the  safe...
Ray backs out of the car and turns around.
...Abby warned me you were gonna  make trouble. Trouble with you is,  you're too fucking obvious; the only  ones with the combination are me and  you...
Ray looks evenly at Meurice. Behind him the sheet has bee arranged over the seat. He puts an unlit cigarette in his mouth.
...and Abby. Maybe. But as far as  I'm concerned that only leaves one  fucking possibility.
(tonelessly) What's that?
Meurice reaches out and swipes the unlit cigarette out of Ray's mouth.
Those things are nothing but coffin  nails.
He turns and stares down the street, exasperated.
...Look. Personally I don't give a  shit. I know Marty's a hard-on but  you gotta do something. I don't know;  give the money back, say you're sorry,  or get the fuck out of here, or  something...
Mow that his temper is gone, he realizes he has nothing m to say. He shakes his head and turns back down the drive, muttering as he lights himself Ray's cigarette.
...It's very humiliating, preaching  about this shit.

Standing in front of the back door of his car, watching  Meurice walk away. His right hand rises into frame to dep another unlit cigarette in his mouth. Offscreen, Meurice  calls from the end of the drive:
I'm not laughing at this, Ray Bob,  so you know it's no fucking joke.

We hear his car door slam. After a moment Ray exits frame heading for the house. The camera tracks slowly in to the back window of the car. Traces of blood are starting to seep up from the upholste into the sheet.

We are looking across the tiled floor toward the front  doorway. The room has the dim gray cast of daytime inside shuttered house. We hold on the empty foyer as we hear an intermittent high whining sound. We hear the padding of f on carpet, and then the clatter of nails on tile as Opal, Marty's German shepherd, trots into frame and circles the foyer, still whining. She jumps up and scratches desperat at the front door. A slow, rhythmic pounding is very faint on the track.

Abby has just gotten out of her car and is walking up to front of the darkened bar. The faint, rhythmic thumping  continues over the cut, its source somewhere offscreen. A Abby takes a key out of her purse and lets herself into t bar, the thumping stops.
Abby switches on the lights, looks around, goes to the ba office door. Locked. As she fits her key into the lock:
(quietly) Marty?
The door swings open, fanning a shaft of light onto the  darkened room.

We are looking from the inside at the bathroom door that  won't close all the way. As the light fans into the offic beyond and seeps in through the crack of the bathroom doo we see Visser's sleeve cuff and his hand pressing against the door, to hold it near-shut.
Standing in the office doorway. We pull her into the room She stops abruptly, looking past the camera, and wrinkles her nose.
Marty's fish, now half-decayed, still lie on the desk. Some of the desk drawers stand open, with some of their  contents strewn across the surface of the desk.
She takes a step forward. We hear the crunch of glass  underfoot. She looks down at the floor.
Shards of broken glass lie on the floor.
She looks up from the floor toward the back door.
The pane of the back-door window closest to the knob has  been shattered from the outside, scattering broken glass  into the office.
She crosses slowly to the desk, staring at the rotted fis She looks up from the desk.

On the standing safe behind the desk lies a white towel.  Abby's hand enters frame ans picks up the towel. In slow motion a hammer that's been wrapped inside slips of the towel, falls end-over-end, hits the floor with a d thud.

Stooping down to pick up the hammer. At eye level as she  stoops down is the combination dial to the safe. The dial has been battered by the hammer. Abby looks from the hamm to the floor under the desk chair.
Blood stains.
Staring down at the floor. She rises and looks at the des As she rises we hear glass under her feet.
The dead fish. Beyond them, on the floor around the desk, broken glass.
Staring.
The dead fish.

She seems to be falling slowly backwards. The camera fall with her, keeping her in close shot. Her head hits a pill We pull back slowly to reveal that she is lying on the be in her apartment, staring across the room. She lies motio on the bad, her eyes wide.
Across the darkened apartment we see the curtainless wind and beyond them, across the lamplit street, the facade of the opposite building.
Lying still. After a moment she gets out of bed, crosses the front door of the apartment, locks it, then walks  unsteadily back to the bed.
She opens her eyes, lies still for a moment, coughs. She  gets out of bed and walks across the still dark apartment the bathroom. She shuts the bathroom door.

Abby looks at herself in the mirror above the sink, then  turns on the tap water. From a neighboring apartment we h a dull rhythmic thumping on the wall. She pauses, listens for a moment, then starts to splash water on her face. From somewhere offscreen we hear the sharp sound of glass shattering. It reverberates for a moment, then dies. Abby looks up at the bathroom door. We hear a scraping at the  lock of her apartment door. Abby listens. Suddenly we hear the lock springing open, and the front d swinging on its hinges.
Startled. She shuts off the water and stands motionless.  Droplets of water are streaming down her face. We hear the sound of footsteps in the next room, crunchin across broken glass.
Ray...?
There is no answer. After a moment we hear bedsprings cre in the next room. Abby opens the bathroom door and walks  out.

A shaft of light slices across the floor from the open  bathroom door. Broken glass glints on the floor. In the s darkness we can see that someone is sitting on the bed. T person looks up. It is Marty. Abby recoils.
Lover-boy oughta lock his door.
Abby looks nervously at Marty. Droplets of water are stil running down her face. She brushes one from her eye.
I love you...
He smiles thinly.
...That's a stupid thing to say,  right?
Abby takes a step back.
I... I love you too.
Still smiling, Marty shakes his head.
No. You're just saying that because  you're scared...
He stands. We hear glass under his feet. He unbuttons the middle button of his coat and reaches inside.
...You left your weapon behind.
He withdraws something from an inside pocket and tosses i to her.
As she catches the object. It is her compact.
She looks from her hands up to Marty.
He'll kill you too.
Marty gags, leans forward, doubles over to vomit--blood. The blood washes over the floor at his feet.
Bolts upright in bead with a muffled groan. Sweat pours d her face. She brushes a drop of sweat from her eye and lo around.

Moonlight glints through the windows across the hardwood  floor. Through the windows we can see the facade of the  opposite building. The apartment is dark and still, just we left it before she fell asleep.

She slumps back onto the bed. One hand gropes down out of frame and comes up holding an illuminated alarm clock. Sh looks at it, drops it back to the floor. She turns on her side and stares across the room toward t window.
The window.
It is still not quite light. The few lights that shined i the windows of the opposite building before are now off; facade of the building is a flat, undetailed gray.
Still lying on her side on the bed, her eyes open, starin at the window.
After a moment Abby enters frame. She picks her coat off chair and puts it on. We hear a car door slam.

Abby has just gotten out of her car in the foreground and crossing the lawn to the house. Down the road the street  lights are still on. One light burns in the house, in the window of Ray's bedroom. Abby approaches it.

Over Abby's shoulder, as she leans against the sill of th open window and looks inside. Ray sits on the bed in the empty room, smoking a cigarett his profile to the window, gazing fixedly at the wall.
Ray.
Ray starts and looks toward the window, squinting.
Abby is coming through the screen door. The room is strik bare of everything except furniture. All personal effects have been removed. Abby looks around, bewildered, as Ray enters from the hal
...Where is everything?
In the trunk.
Abby, still standing in front of the door, looks at him  uncomprehendingly. Ray walks over to a couple of cardboar boxes stacked in the corner.
...In the car.
He ties a knot around the top carton with a piece of cord then cuts the cord with a collapsible fishing knife.
...You leaving?
Isn't that what you want?
She slowly shakes her head.
Wanna come with me?
He leans back against the boxes, watching her.
...But first I gotta know what  happened.
What do you want to know?
You broke into the bar. You wanted  to get your money. You and Marty had  a fight. Something happened...
Ray shakes his head, smiling. Abby squints at him, lookin for help.
...I don't know, wasn't it you? Maybe  a burglar broke in, and you found--
With your gun?...
He puts the knife in his pocket and walks over to the doo As he approaches her:
...Nobody broke in, Abby. I'll tell  you the truth...
Ray faces Abby in front of the door.
...Truth is, I've felt sick the last  couple of days. Can't eat... Can't  sleep... When I try to I... Abby...
It's difficult to bring out. Ray's hand gropes for the cr slat on the screen door. Finally:
...The truth is... he was alive when  I buried him.

Abby stares. An object materializes in the sky beyond them. It is flip end-over-end in slow motion, moving toward Abby and Ray a the screen door. Abby and Ray, each staring at the other, fail to notice until-- THWACK--it bounces off the screen. Abby starts; Ray doesn't. The spell is broken, Abby pushes hesitantly at the screen door. Ray's hand slides off the cross-slat; he makes no m to stop her.
As Abby steps over the rolled-up newspaper that hit the s door.
Hurrying down the driveway to get to her car. A low rumbl is building on the soundtrack. Abby glances at Ray's car she passes it.
More blood has seeped into and dried on the dropsheet cov the back seat. The bass rumble grows louder, punctuated b rhythmic thumping.

As she pounds frantically on the door--the sound continui over the cut. After a moment the door edges open. Meurice is standing in the doorway in a long bathrobe. A  sleeper's blindfold is pushed up over his forehead.
Abby. What's the matter?
I... I'm sorry, Meurice. I gotta  talk to you... Can I come in?
He looks at her hard.
Yeah... yeah, come in...
He steps aside to let her pass.
...but I gotta tell ya...
As Abby enters.
...I'm retired.
Meurice switches on a table lamp; the curtains are drawn  against the sun. Abby follows Meurice over to the bar.
Jesus, I got a hangover. Want a drink?
No, I--
Well I do...
He pours himself a drink.
...For you I answer the door. If you  wanna stay here, that's fine. But  I'm retired.
Something happened with Marty and  Ray--
(sharply) Abby...
He glares at her.
...Let me ask you one question...
He slams back the drink.
...Why do you think I'm retired.
He grimaces.
...Ray stole a shitload of money  from Marty. Until both of 'em calm  down I'm not getting involved.
No Meurice, it's worse than that.  Something really happened, I think  Marty's dead--
What?! Did Ray tell you that?
Sort of...
Meurice sits her down on the sofa.
That's total bullshit. Marty called  me after he was jacked up...
He tries to coax her into lying down.
...I mean, I don't know where he is,  but he ain't dead.
Meurice--
You don't look too good. You sleep  last night?
Her head meets an end cushion.
Meurice, you gotta help me...
Meurice rises from the sofa, sighs.
All right. Just sit tight. Try to  get some sleep...
He leans down to the table next to the sofa.
...I'll find Marty, find out what's  going on.
Her head on the cushion. We hear engine rumble. Abby twis her head back, following Meurice. As we hear the table la being switched off we:
The engine rumble continues over the cut. There is no oth traffic on the highway. A light fog covers the road. A gr highway sign says: "San Antonio 73 mi." We hear a car rad playing softly.

Driving. He is gently lit by the light from the dashboard He reaches forward to turn off the radio. The only sound is the hum of the engine and the rhythmic clomping of tir on pavement. The look and sound of the scene are close to those of the first scene of the movie. Ray takes a cigarette out of his pocket and puts it in hi mouth, but leaves it unlit.
The headlights of an approaching car materialize in the f The car passes with a roar. Up ahead a traffic light is turning amber.
The engine hum drops as he slows. We hear the low engine  rumble and the squeaking brakes of another car. Ray is no stopped in front of the deserted intersection. He looks u in his rearview mirror.
Another car is stopped just behind him, the fog floating past its headlights. The headlights halate in the fog; no of the rest of the car is visible.

The unlit cigarette still in his mouth. He looks down fro the rearview mirror to the intersection ahead of him. The is a long pause, during which we hear only the steady pur of Ray's car and the knocking rumble of the car behind hi Ray looks up at the traffic light.
The light is just turning from red to green.
He takes his foot off the brake, hesitates for a moment, replaces it on the brake.
He looks up in his rearview mirror.
The headlights of the other car remain motionless behind  him. The car makes no move to pass.
