He slowly takes the cigarette from his mouth and drops it onto the seat next to him. His eyes shift from the rearvi mirror to the traffic light.
Green fog floats past the green light.
His face frozen. He turns slowly to look behind.
The other car is still motionless. We hear the muted rumb of its engine.
His eyes shift back to the mirror. He gropes for his wind handle and slowly rolls it down. He sticks out his left a eyes still on the rearview mirror, and waves for the othe car to go around him.
The other car remains still for a moment. White fog float up beyond the red fog created by Ray's brake lights. Finally the car pulls out slowly to the left to pass.
Watching the car pass.

As the car pulls out into the light from the intersection and Ray's headlights, we see that it is a battered green  Volkswagon. First the car itself, and then its red tail  lights, disappear into the fog.
Watching, for a long moment. Finally he takes his foot off the brake, turns the steeri wheel hard left and hangs a U-turn.
A light is switched on in the expensively appointed room. Meurice enters, walking silently on the carpet, looking a the room. He throws the light off at the far end and leav

The door swings open.  Meurice throws the switch near the door and the room is bathed in light. We are once again i the bedroom where we earlier saw Abby looking through her purses. We start to hear the faint buzzing of a fly. Meurice glances around, throws off the light, and shuts t door. Black.
Somewhere offscreen a light is switched on and we are loo in close shot at the dead fish. The sound of the fly is louder with the cut.
Standing in the doorway from the bar, staring down at the fish.
Ray glances around at the broken glass lying on the floor His gaze shifts to the safe and the hammer in front of it He walks over to the safe and stoops down.
He works its battered dial and it swings open. He shuffle through the contents and brings out a small pile of  photographs.
As he flips through the photographs. The first four are R and Abby in the motel room bed. The last is a mounted 8 x 10: Abby and Marty on a Gulf beach.
Looking.
Marty is still laughing.
He scowls at the shots Visser took, then puts them back i the safe. When his hand comes out he is holding another  photograph--this one folded twice. He unfolds it.
His and Abby's corpses.

head_text.subj: BACK TO RAY FROM ACROSS THE DESK

text: As he straightens slowly from the safe in the background. At desk level, we again see the glint of Visser's lighter under the dead fish. Ray crosses slowly around the desk into the foreground an lays the picture flat on the desktop. For a moment he sta down at it, then wheels abruptly and leaves frame.
Driving. He glances up in the rearview mirror.

As Meurice enters and throws an overhead light. The white room is bathed in bright, shadowless light. As Meurice st into the kitchen his foot strikes something on the floor  below frame, which clatters hollowly away.
The empty bowl skids into a wall, bounces back, and wobbl spinning on its bottom rim.
On a low skewed axis the camera is tracking in toward the impassive trophy head on Marty's billiard-room wall. The moose still has Ray's cigarette protruding from its m
As he walks toward the moose, head cocked to one side,  frowning quizzically up. He hears something, and looks through the door to his lef
The long shadowy hall. We hear panting.
Squinting.
...Opal?
A form starts to materialize in the shadows.
Taking a step back.
The dog bounding down the hallway. Its panting has become low growl.
He wrenches a cue stick from the rack and squares.
Opal snarling, leaping.
The splintered top half of the pool cue is slammed down t rest on top of the coffee table.
Even the fucking dog's gone crazy...
Sitting on the sofa, looking down out of frame. Behind he Meurice agitatedly paces back and forth, waving the splin bottom half of the cue stick. His voice is unnaturally lo

...Something pretty fucking weird is  going on. Put your coat on and I'll  drop you at home. But don't talk to  either of 'em until I do. And don't  worry. Believe me. These things always  have a logical explanation. Usually.
The splintered top half of the cue stick on the coffee ta
Abby approaches her door in the foreground and lets herse in.

Looking toward the window. The room is dark. Through the  window we see the facade of the building across the stree Abby enters frame in the foreground, in silhouette agains the window, and throws an overhead light switch. The brig light reveals Ray standing by the window, looking out.
(abruptly) Turn it off.
Abby jumps, startled.
Ray...

From the roof of the building across the street we are lo down on the facade of Abby's building. Most of its window are dark, but in a brightly lit fourth-floor window we ca clearly see Abby and Ray. A man is on the roof in the foreground, hitching a rifle his shoulder.
Ray turns from the window which, with the switching on of the overhead light, has become a mirror of the interior o the apartment.
Just turn it off.
The light goes out in the apartment across the street; it window goes opaque.
Dark now. Ray still stands by the window, looking out. Ab still stands by the light switch.
(answering a question) No curtains on the windows.
Abby is clearly apprehensive--about Ray, not about anythi outside.
I think someone's watching.
Abby doesn't understand, and has had enough. As she throw the light back on:
So what'll they see?
Ray turns angrily from the window.
Just leave it off. He can see in.
Ray and Abby are once again clearly visible. Ray is start across the room.
Abby takes a fearful step back as Ray strides toward the  light switch, next to her.
(abruptly) --If you do anything the neighbors'll  hear.
This brings Ray up short. He stares at Abby. It registers that it is him she's afraid of.
You think...
He shakes his head.
...Abby. I meant it... when I  called...
Abby takes another step back. Her voice comes out, after pause, half-strangled:
...I love you too.
Ray winces. He slowly shakes his head with a pained half- smile.
Because you're scared.
We hear the dull report of a rifle and the deafening soun of shattering glass. The gun shot hits Ray in the back,  knocking him to the floor. He lies still.
She stares dumbly down at Ray. She looks slowly up to the window.
It has a gaping black hole. The sound of shattering glass still reverberates in the apartment. Small shards of glas chink down from the window and shatter on the floor.
Staring at the window, paralyzed--almost in a trance. Qui except for the chinking of glass.
We are looking through the telescopic sight of a high-pow rifle. The rifle sweeps up from Ray's body across the bri lit room, and centers Abby, still staring at the window, the cross hairs.

We are looking past Abby toward the shattered window at t far end of the room. A brass lamp stands in the foregroun between Abby and the camera. Abby still stands paralyzed. Glass has stopped chinking from the window to the floor;  there is a painful silence. Suddenly Abby dives to the floor just as CRASH the rest o the window falls away and PING the brass lamp somersaults toward us from the impact of the bullet. The window is now completely gone--just a black hole in t brightly lit wall.
Scrambles into a corner at the window end of the room. Th only sound is her heavy breathing. She looks over at Ray, then up at the bulb on the ceiling.
Breathing heavily, almost hysterical. She looks down at t floor.
Ray is sprawled on the floor in a pool of blood and broke glass.

She reaches down and pulls off one of her shoes. She thro it at the ceiling bulb. We hear the bulb shatter and the room goes black. Abby rises and makes her way cautiously across the glass- littered floor toward Ray. She stoops over him.
Its front door in background. Abby rises into frame and b toward the doorway, staring down at the floor. One of her hands is covered with blood.
Ray--
She winces and almost loses her balance as we hear a piec of glass crunching under her bare floor. She turns and mo to the front door, favoring one foot, and throws the door open.
Abby lurches from her apartment and pounds on the neighbo door. No answer. She pounds on the door across the hall.
(frightened, in Spanish) Get away! I'll call my son-in-law!
(groping for the words,  in Spanish) No no--you don't understand--
(in Spanish) He has a gun!
Abby heads for the stairway at the far end of the hall. T heel of her shod foot is throwing her weight onto her bad foot; she kicks off the shoe.

As she reaches the top of the stairs. She takes one step  down, then brings herself up short. She looks over the ra down the stairwell. It is quiet. An innocent-sounding cou echoes somewhere in the building. We hear the sound of footsteps from somewhere below. Abby turns and hobbles back to her apartment.
